Posts.Title: Mastectomy on wednesday..any advice/tips?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone  Quick q if I may. I was diagnosed with stage 2 lobular BC in my left Breast last November. Since then I've had a mx (no lymph node involvement) & immediate recon, gave Chemo a swerve and went straight to 15 sessions of rads. I've been taking Anastrozole for the last 3 and a half months. I started with Accord brand but experienced sever joint pain - to the point where I could barely hold a pen & my 89 year old mother was getting out of a chair quicker thank I was. I also experienced severe rib pain. I switched to arimidex and the symptoms were much reduced. But last weekend the rib pain started again but this time on my RIGHT side. It's now v severe. And again I'm having problems getting out of a chair ( should I change my chairs ?!!) I'm pretty sure it's the ARIMIDEX but it is super painful & of course my normally subjective Brain has started to go into overdrive.I've started my phased return, but am now dreading long car journeys etc as I understand the OCCH Doc is quite unsympathetic. Anyway this is a long bc winded way of asking if anyone else has experienced the stabbing rib pain on ny version of Anastrozole plse ? I've been told repeatedly that I no longer have any cancer left after they removed my tumour- but with this pain, I'm imaging the worst ! Thanks for your help in advance.
Posts.Title: Rib Pain - Arimidex

Posts.Content: Hi AndyLou.. I had mine just before Xmas.  I agree with Maxine.. also suggest front fastening bras too - I bought a couple from Amazon .. they were easier to do up initially, when arm movement is a bit limited.  I also bought a couple of blouses/shirts to button up the front - I normally wear t shirt type tops and they would have defeated me in the first few days! I also borrowed a couple of my husbands shirts to ring the changes. Cardigans are great too. I was given my little cotton bag for the drains. I also took in front fastening night shirt for the hospital stay. I also borrowed a travel kettle for the first few weeks .. we have a heavy kettle normally and when no one was at home I couldn't lift that to make a cuppa - it was invaluable when everyone went back to work or college and couldn't be my willing slave !  If you have access to an A frame pillow too .. that might help sleeping at night - i found sleeping on my back tricky and this helped me feel supported & less vulnerable.  Good luck for Wednesday ... I was very relieved to have it over when mine was done ... although it wasn't the Xmas present I'd really wanted, it's all healed now !  Oh one final thought - so try and do the arm exercises they give you.  They maybe tricky at first but pay dividends in the end.

Posts.Title: Post Drain Pain

Posts.Content: Hi Rachel, I had a skin sparing mastectomy just before Xmas. I had one sentinel node removed & a reconstruction at the same time. Your bag list sounds about right .. I took some starbursts in too ! It was SO hot they gave me a small fan to have on my new side table to keep me cool - it was a lifesaver !! I had drains for a few days, and was given a cotton bag to carry them around in. I was concerned about dealing with them before I went in, but it was all very straightforward & I shouldn't have worried ! I didn't have any bras given to me, I took in a couple of front fasteners, and front fastening Jammies. I was allowed back driving after 6 weeks (I live in a rural area too, so this was a challenge - thank heavens for friends) , I was recommended not to lift anything heavier than a 2lb bag of sugar and no housework for 3 months.  I'll be honest with you, I found the enforced sitting down and healing very frustrating as I'm used to dashing about & multitaking. But I also didn't want the implant to swivel round and be left with a new boob at a jaunty angle while at the healing stage - so unusually for me I followed the advice to the letter. I, too, was told to keep up with the painkillers .. I had paracetamol (and codeine for a short time). I tried to do gentle walks as often as I could - but some days , the sofa & catch-up TV was the preferred option ( concentrating on books was tricky for a bit - so short articles and puzzles it was !)  !  Hope that's some help ... Good Luck !  All best wishes  Sarah
Posts.Title: Pre-mastectomy and implant recon nerves

Posts.Content: hi Ossy, plse don't feel ashamed .. you've had major surgery, you've had a huge shock .. and the reality may probably only just be setting in.i too go through phases of weeping, wailing and gnashing my teeth & I'm 6 months down the road since my mastectomy. I've had radiotherapy but feel guilty about feeling so down, when I know others have so much to cope with. But we all do things differently. We all have our own cancer, our own fears and demons. We've all had a brush with something we'd rather not have had to face. I'm on hormone treatment now for 5 yrs and some of my ups and downs I can put down to that, but a lot of it is the shock settling now active treatment has finished. Everyone is expecting me to go back to normal, but every time I look in the mirror I know it can never go back to how it was. And I find that hard.  So plse don't be ashamed. I have plucked up the courage to have a few sessions of counselling.  I think it's helping ... I'm reluctant to go down the anti depressant route .. but if i don't settle soon I may do that for a while. You may not want any of that at all - a coffee & chat with others who 'get it' might be exactly what YOU need.   Everyone's different. Plse find something that works for you... but above all plse don't feel ashamed. X

Posts.Title: Help Oncotype result!! Advice please x

Posts.Content: I had the oncotype test and went all round the houses trying to decide what to do if I came back in the middle ranking. It was a long two week wait - really messed with my head. I was told pre onco type testing that chemo could give me around 2% benefit. But I was very nervous about saying yes to it (i felt it wasn't something to enter into lightly) ... but I was equally nervous saying no. I was coming down on the side of saying yes to chemo toward the end of my deliberations, but ultimately, I was lucky that my results came back indicting I would have less than 1% benefit .. so the negatives outweighed any possible positives. It gave me the confidence to say no to chemo ( although I do have the occasional worry I may have made the wrong decision). I ended up with Rads after my mastectomy & am now on anastrozole.   I don't think this post is probably any help at all, but I just wanted to say I completely 'get' your dilemma and am thinking of you.  It's such a personal decision and whatever you decide will be right for you. Good Luck, whatever you decide. X
